title: Rainbow Graphs in Balanced Edge-Colorings
description: Characterize graphs G such that every balanced edge-coloring of K_n contains a rainbow copy of G. K_4 fails (Clemen-Wagner 2023), but full characterization is open.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #811 concerns rainbow subgraphs in balanced edge-colorings. The problem was posed by Erdős, Pyber, and Tuza (1991). A balanced coloring of K_n with m colors requires each vertex to see exactly ⌊n/m⌋ edges of each color (only possible when n ≡ 1 mod m). A rainbow subgraph uses each color at most once. The question asks which graphs G are guaranteed to appear as rainbow subgraphs in every balanced coloring of K_n. Recent work by Clemen-Wagner (2023) and Axenovich-Clemen (2024) has resolved some cases negatively.
overview.problemStatement:
For which graphs G is it true that if m = e(G), for all large n ≡ 1 (mod m), every balanced edge-coloring of K_n with m colors contains a rainbow copy of G?

Specific challenge: In any balanced 6-coloring of K_{6n+1}, must there exist a rainbow C_6 or rainbow K_4?

Known: K_4 does NOT have this property (Clemen-Wagner 2023). Infinitely many complete graphs fail (Axenovich-Clemen 2024).
overview.proofStrategy: This problem remains OPEN. Our formalization defines edge colorings, balanced colorings, rainbow subgraphs, and the rainbow property for graphs. We axiomatize known results: Erdős-Tuza bounds for C_4, Clemen-Wagner's disproof for K_4, and Axenovich-Clemen's result showing infinitely many K_m fail. We also state their conjecture that all K_m fail for m ≥ 4.
keyInsights: A balanced coloring exists only when n ≡ 1 (mod m), ensuring equal color distribution
K_4 lacks the rainbow property: there exist balanced 6-colorings of K_n without rainbow K_4
Axenovich-Clemen conjecture: K_m fails for all m ≥ 4
The quantitative version studies d_G(n), the minimum degree threshold for rainbow G
Erdős's specific challenge about C_6 and K_4 in 6-colorings remains open

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #811 asks which graphs G are guaranteed rainbow copies in every balanced edge-coloring. K_4 is now known to fail. The full characterization of graphs with this property remains open.
conclusion.implications: This problem connects Ramsey theory (unavoidable substructures) with graph coloring (chromatic structures). The failure of K_4 suggests that even highly symmetric graphs may lack the rainbow property, potentially due to algebraic constructions avoiding rainbow complete graphs.
openQuestions: Which specific graphs G have the rainbow property?
Does the Axenovich-Clemen conjecture hold for all K_m with m ≥ 4?
What about cycles? Does C_6 have the property in 6-colorings?
Can we characterize graphs by structural properties that predict the rainbow property?
